reasoningQuestions.topText: Ira uses a heater with unknown power, $!$P$!$, to heat up an open container with 2 kg of water. The initial temperature of the container is $!$60^{\circ}C$!$ and the heater is kept on till the temperature reaches $!$120^{\circ}C$!$. The total time taken is $!$10\:min$!$. The specific heat capacity of water, $!$c_w$!$, is $!$4200\:J/kg/K$!$, the specific heat capacity of steam, $!$c_s$!$, is $!$2000\:J/kg/K$!$, and the latent heat of vaporisation of water, $!$L$!$, is $!$2.26\times10^6\:J/kg$!$. Assuming that the container is insulated, Ira calculates the power of the heater to be $!$693.33\:W$!$ (upto 2 decimal places) which does not match it's actual power rating.

answerOptions.optionText: Energy supplied by heater ($!$Q$!$) = $!$mc\Delta T_1 + mc\Delta T_2$!$
Energy supplied by heater ($!$Q$!$) = $!$mc\Delta T_1 + mc\Delta T_2 + mL$!$

reasoningQuestions.topText: Two blocks of the same cross-sectional area, $!$A$!$, are joined together. The left end of the first block is held at a constant temperature of $!$200\:K$!$ and the right end of the second block is held at a constant temperature of $!$750\:K$!$. The first block has a length of $!$2l$!$ and a conductivity of $!$3k$!$ and the second block has a length of $!$l$!$ and a conductivity of $!$k$!$. At steady state, Ira calculates the temperature, $!$T$!$, of the point where the blocks are joined to be $!$567\:K$!$. However, this turns out to be incorrect.

answerOptions.optionText: Heat flow through the first block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_1}{\Delta t}$!$) = $!$\frac{3kA(T - 200)}{2l}$!$
Heat flow through the second block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_2}{\Delta t}$!$) = $!$\frac{kA(750 - T)}{l}$!$
$!$T$!$ is found using heat flow through the first block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_1}{\Delta t}$!$) = $!$3 \times$!$ heat flow through the second block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_2}{\Delta t}$!$)
Heat flow through the first block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_1}{\Delta t}$!$) = $!$\frac{m \cdot 3k \cdot (T - 200)}{\Delta t}$!$
Heat flow through the second block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_2}{\Delta t}$!$) = $!$\frac{m \cdot k \cdot (750 - T)}{\Delta t}$!$
$!$T$!$ is found using heat flow through the first block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_1}{\Delta t}$!$) = heat flow through the second block ($!$\frac{\Delta Q_2}{\Delta t}$!$)
